persName.addName: Barber, barber artist, barber painter, Mr Kaye
persName.note: John Kay (1742–1826), portrait etcher and miniature painter, worked as barber in Edinburgh for seven years, thereby earning the nickname used for him throughout this correspondence. In December 1777 he purchased the freedom of the city and was able to start a business of his own, whilst an annuity granted in 1785 allowed him to give up his work as a barber and concentrate on creating caricature portraits, which he sold from his shop. Plans for publishing his work, which amounted to almost 900 plates, were incomplete at the time of his death. His work favoured liberals but was broad in its scope and its witty portrayal of Edinburgh society. ODNB.

Moses Griffith (1747–1819) [+Margaret Griffith (née Jones) and Moses junior], watercolour painter and engraver, born in Caernarvonshire. He was employed as member of the household by Thomas Pennant from 1769 and continued to receive patronage from the Pennant family even after the death of Thomas Pennant. He accompanied Pennant on his 1769 and 1772 Scottish tours, his illustrations published in A tour in Scotland and voyage to the Hebrides in 1774, and was also the illustrator for his Welsh tours. Moses Griffith married Margaret Jones on 9 January 1781, and they had two children, Moses and Margaret. ODNB.

A watercolour drawing of two horned cattle pulling a plough, lead and goaded by a native Indian signed 'Moses Griffith junior fecit 1798', and entitled 'Aryut at Plough' is found in an extra-illustrated copy of The View of Hindoostan. Vol. II. Eastern Hindoostan (London: J. White, M.DCC.XCVIII) (NLW 23413E).

Roger Mostyn (1734–96), 5th baronet, of Mostyn, Flintshire, and Gloddaeth, Caernarvonshire. He married Margaret, daughter of Rev. Hugh Wynn, Bodysgallen and Berthddu, and his wife, Catherine. He was a vice-president of the Welsh Charity School in London, and his Welsh cultural interests are signalled by the dedication of Evan Evans's Some Specimens of the Poetry of the Antient Welsh Bards (1764) to him. In December 1792 he became a member of the Loyalist Flintshire Association promoted by his brother-in-law, Thomas Pennant. Mostyn's relationship with Pennant is evinced in the latter's correspondence from Pennant's frequent use of franks in his name. DWB; History of Parliament on-line.

Benjamin White (c. 1725–1794), younger brother of Gilbert White, author of Natural History of Selborne (1789), to whom he introduced Pennant. He published eight of Pennant’s books. White's son Benjamin was involved in the business from 1785, and the firm was renamed Benjamin White & Son, with the elder White retiring in 1792, by which time another son, John, had also become involved in the company. ODNB.

ODNB entry:(1746/7–1820), antiquary, was born Adam Cardonnel; he was a great-nephew of Adam de Cardonnel, secretary to the duke of Marlborough, and the sole surviving son of Mansfeldt de Cardonnel (1696/7–1780), of Musselburgh, a commissioner of the customs and salt duties in Scotland, and his wife, Anne, the daughter and heir of Thomas Hilton of Low Ford, co. Durham. After being educated for the medical profession he practised for a while in Edinburgh as a surgeon, but his easy circumstances left him leisure to indulge his interest in the study of antiquities and numismatics. Upon the institution of the Society of Antiquaries of Scotland, under the presidency of the earl of Bute, in December 1780, Cardonnel was elected a fellow; he also served as curator from 1782 to 1784, and contributed to the second volume of the Archaeologia Scotica (1.159–67), ‘A description of certain Roman ruins discovered at Inveresk’. He also produced Numismata Scotiae, or, A Series of Scottish Coinage (1786), which he illustrated himself. Although it was largely derived from Thomas Snelling's View of the Silver Coin and Coinage of Scotland (1774), it contained some interesting historical material and was regarded as generally accurate. Cardonnel also published, in four parts, Picturesque Antiquities of Scotland (1788–93), etched by himself; a second edition in one volume was published in 1802. When Francis Grose visited Scotland, Cardonnel, who then resided at Edinburgh, assisted his brother antiquary with notes from his extensive collections, besides accompanying him on various archaeological expeditions, attentions that Grose acknowledged in the introduction to his Antiquities of Scotland. In the autumn of 1789 Burns addressed a letter to Grose, under cover to Cardonnel at Edinburgh. While in the act of folding it up the quaint old song of ‘Sir John Malcolm’ ran through his mind, and he inscribed within the wrapper his well-known impromptu ‘Ken ye ought o' Captain Grose?’ (J. Kinsley, ed., Poems and Songs, 1968, 564).

Charles Cordiner (1746?–1794), minister of St Andrew’s Chapel, Banff, and author of Antiquities and Scenery in the North of Scotland, in a Series of Letters to Thomas Pennant (1780) and Remarkable ruins and romantic prospects of north Britain, with ancient monuments and singular subjects of natural history (2 vols., 1788–95), which originally appeared in numbers and for which he provided images, engraved by James Basire and others. Pennant considered the Antiquities and Scenery to be an extension of his own 1769 and 1772 Scottish tours. ODNB; Murdo MacDonald, ‘Towards Celtic Revival Art in Scotland: The Visual Background to Revival in the 18th and 19th Centuries’, in Romantic Ireland: From Tone to Gonne: Fresh Perspectives on Nineteenth-Century Ireland, ed. by Paddy Lyons, Willy Maley and John Miller (Newcastle upon Tyne: Cambridge Scholars Publishing, 2013), pp. 160–19, esp. p. 162.

Joseph Edmondson (bap. 1732, d. 1786), herald and coach-painter, who made his name among the nobility following the publication from 1764 of an updated version of the Baronagium genealogicum, a manuscript collection of the pedigrees of peers, initially in numbers. Further works included the notable two-volume A Complete Body of Heraldry (1780). Edmondson died on 17 February 1786. His library, of which the British Library holds a printed catalogue, was sold in 1788. The son named by Bull in TP189/6 was probably his elder son, Philip (b. 1756?), who continued his father's prosperous coach-painting business. ODNB.

The publications of the antiquary Richard Gough (1735–1809) included an edition of Camden’s Britannia (1789), which was achieved using a network of antiquarian friends and correspondents. His Sepulchral Monuments (2 vols. and later introduction, 1786, 1796, 1799), was intended to illustrate the ‘history of the Families, Manners, Habits and Arts from the Norman conquest’, and valued chiefly for its illustrations, engraved by James Basire. Director of the Society of Antiquaries (1771–97), fellow of the Royal Society (1775–95) and regular correspondent with the Gentleman's Magazine, Gough was enabled to commit himself unreservedly to his own antiquarian researches and to helping other antiquaries from a position of independent fortune, conferred upon him on the deaths of his parents in 1751 and 1774. ODNB.

Francis Grose (bap. 1731, d. 1791), an antiquary who popularized the field of antiquarianism. Known as 'Captain Grose' following his promotion to captain in the Surrey regiment of the militia in 1765, Grose had shown an early interest in sketching. In 1772 he published the first number of The Antiquities of England and Wales, a work in an innovative format offering a series of engravings alongside descriptive text, the latter sometimes taken (with acknowledgement) from published books or from fellow antiquaries, at other times from material collected through correspondence. Tours in 1788, 1789 and 1790 lead to the publication of The Antiquities of Scotland, but Grose died in Dublin before he had much made progress on a companion study, The Antiquities of Ireland. ODNB.

Henry Hughs (or Hughes) was a Fleet Street (see Evans, 274) printer involved in the printing of Pennant's two-volume A tour in Wales in 1778, 1781 and 1783, together with Supplemental plates to the tours in Wales in 1781 and an edition subtitled Supplemental corrections and additions to the first volume of the Welsh Tour in 1784. He was the printer of Arctic zoology (2 vols.; 1784, 1785); The view of Hindoostan (1798); and a second edition of Indian zoology ('for R. Faulder', 1790). He may be the 'Hughes' named alongside 'West', from no. 40, Paternoster Row, as sellers of Pennant's posthumously-published A tour from Downing to Alston-Moor and A journey from London to the Isle of Wight (both in 1801). Pennant’s references to his base in Turnstile, Holborn, suggests a relation with John Hughs (d.?1771 /1774), printer to House of Commons, of the same address. In 1796 he gave his address as King's Road, Bedford Row. Jerry White, A Great and Monstrous Thing: London in the Eighteenth Century (London 2012), p. 263; Francis Cecil Doherty, A Study in Eighteenth-century Advertising Methods: The Anodyne Necklace, p. 390; Evans, ‘Richard Bull and Thomas Pennant’, 274.

Peter Mazell was the son of French Huguenots parents living in Dublin, and worked as a painter and engraver from various London addresses, including at Portland Street (1783) and Covent Garden (1791), during c.1761–1797. An exhibitor of paintings of landscapes and flowers, his engravings of natural history subjects was a notable part of the productions of authors including John Walcott and Thomas Pennant. His natural history illustrations for the latter involved the use of paintings of birds by Peter Paillou in British Zoology, History of Quadrupeds, Arctic Zoology and Tour of Wales, 1778, and he was also the engraver and publisher of the work of Pennant's protégé Charles Cordiner, Remarkable ruins and romantic prospects of north Britain, with ancient monuments and singular subjects of natural history (London: P. Mazell, 1788–[95]).

FROM ODNB - YORKE CONNECTION MAKES IT LIKELY HE FRANKED ONE OF TP'S LETTERS: Samuel Salter (bap. 1713, d. 1778), Church of England clergyman, was born in the parish of St Stephen, Norwich, and baptized there on 8 December 1713. He was educated at the free school in Norwich, the Charterhouse in London (1728–30), and, like his father, at Corpus Christi College, Cambridge, from where he matriculated in 1730. Here he graduated BA in 1734 and MA in 1737, and was a fellow from 1735 to 1738. About 1734, on the recommendation of Thomas Herring, then dean of Rochester, he became tutor to Philip Yorke (later second earl of Hardwicke), the son of Lord Chief Justice Hardwicke. In 1737 Hardwicke became lord chancellor and Salter quickly benefited from his patronage. Hardwicke appointed Salter his domestic chaplain and had him preferred to a prebend in Gloucester Cathedral in 1739, and to the rectory of Burton Coggles, Lincolnshire, in 1740. Salter married Elizabeth Secker, a relative of Thomas Secker, the future archbishop, in November 1744; they left two daughters and a son, Philip, who later became vicar of Shenfield in Essex. In 1751 Herring, now archbishop of Canterbury, awarded Salter a Lambeth DD. Eventually Hardwicke saw that he also acquired, in 1756, the rectory of St Bartholomew by the Exchange, which he held jointly with his Charterhouse appointments. Salter's Norwich connections also yielded fruit. In 1745 his father personally installed him to a prebend in Norwich Cathedral, which he held until his death, and he was for a time (1750–54) vicar of Great Yarmouth. By 1778 he was also the official to the archdeacon of Norfolk. A scholar versed in the classics, his publications included a contribution to Athenian Letters (1741–3), principally the work of his pupil Philip Yorke, and editions of Richard Bentley's Dissertation upon the Epistles of Phalaris (1777) and Benjamin Whichcot's Moral and Religious Aphorisms (1753). His published sermons include one preached before the lord mayor of London on 2 September 1740, the anniversary fast commemorating the great fire of London. Salter began his Charterhouse years in 1754, first as preacher but in effect as deputy master; and then, in 1761, he became master. Here he tried to regularize inefficiencies perhaps too pedantically; he soon developed acrimonious relationships with his registrars and officials over bureaucratic minutiae. He died on 2 May 1778 at the Charterhouse, where he was buried two days later, as he wished, in the common burial-ground, without slab or monument to his memory. His wife survived him.

Peter Burrell III, first Baron Gwydir (1754–1820) of Langley Park, Beckenham, Kent, was the only son of Peter Burrell II. He was knighted 6 July 1781, succeeded his uncle Sir Merrick Burrell as second Baronet on 6 April 1787, and was created Baron Gwydir on 16 June 1796. He was known to Horace Walpole and Anthony Morris Storer as a fortunate and wealthy man. History of Parliament; ODNB s.v. White Conduit cricket club (act. c.1785–1788).

Elizabeth Pennant (née Falconer, d. June 1764) was the daughter of James Faulkner of Chester, Lieutenant, and his wife Elizabeth (née Inge). Pennant married her in April 1759. She was the mother of Thomas (who died at two months in 1760), Arabella and David.

Paul Panton (1727–1797), born in Bagillt, Flintshire, to an old Welsh family of noble descent, was educated at Trinity Hall, Cambridge, and entered Lincoln's Inn in December 1744. Through his marriage in 1756 to Jane, daughter and heir of William Jones of Plas Gwyn, Pentraeth, Anglesey, he became the owner of a substantial estate and a contributor to public life in Anglesey. He continued to interest himself in his native Flintshire, becoming involved in particular in its increasing industrialization. Like Pennant, a close friend, he travelled in England, Wales and Scotland; as an antiquarian, he was interested in Welsh history and literature and notably, patronized the impoverished clergyman, Evan Evans (Ieuan Fardd). He died on 22 May 1797.

Thomas Pennant was the son of David Pennant (d.1763), landowner, and a member of the Pennant family who owned the estate centred upon an ancient house at Bychton since Norman conquest. Pennant's mother was Arabella, (d. 1744), 3rd daughter of Richard Mytton, of Halston, Shropshire. ODNB.
Pennant’s 'very antient aunt', Possibly Elizabeth (d.1775). See Pennant, Whiteford and Holywell

Arabella Pennant (b.1761, d. 1828, according to ancestry.co.uk) was the daughter of Thomas Pennant by his first wife, Elizabeth (née Falconer). As a young woman she divided her time between Downing and the home of her aunt, Catherine Pennant, at Upper Grosvenor Street in London, and upon the latter's death appears to have inherited a substantial sum of money. Her financial independence is signalled by her contribution of £25 to the fund for setting up 'The Loyal Holywell Volunteers' in March 1797, and by her decision to marry, against her father's wishes, Edward, son of Sir Walden Hanmer, in November 1797. Her father's will of February 1798 granted her a limited settlement, but a codicil in August of the same year granted additional sums for Arabella, her husband and any children (of which there were none). ODNB; John Burke, A genealogical and heraldic history of the commoners of Great Britain and Ireland, enjoying territorial possessions or high official rank; but uninvested with heritable honours (4 vols., London: Henry Colburn, 1836), III, p. 34; Evans, 'The Flintshire Loyalist Association and the Loyal Holywell Volunteers', 62; Evans, 'The life and work of Thomas Pennant', pp. 71–2.
Sarah Pennant (1779–94) was the daughter of Thomas Pennant and his second wife, Anne (née Mostyn). She died at Brighton on 16 April 1794. ODNB; Evans, 'The life and work of Thomas Pennant', pp. 73–4.

David Pennant (1763–1841), son of Thomas Pennant by his first wife, Elizabeth (née Falconer). Following study at Christ Church, Oxford, David Pennant undertook three tours of the continent, in 1785–6, 1787–8 and 1791–2. His father's involvement in these tours is evinced in correspondence to David at Yverdon, Paris and Rome, and in the grateful recognition of David's assistance in Literary Life. Travels in Britain were recorded in accounts of tours to the Lake District and from London to Chester in 1789 and 1792 respectively (NLW 2423B), and records of travel in Yorkshire and Derbyshire, c.1792–1800, in Cheltenham and the Wye in 1792, and to Burley on the Hill [Rutland] in 1800 (WCRO CR 2017/TP 73). David Pennant edited and published posthumously his father’s A Journey from London to the Isle of Wight (1801); A Tour from Downing to Alston Moor (1801); and A Tour from Alston Moor to Harrowgate and Brimham Crags (1804). He also arranged the publication of four volumes of Pennant's Outlines of the Globe, the third and fourth of which he edited himself. David became JP for Flintshire in 1787, captain of the Loyal Holywell Volunteer Corps in 1797, and High Sheriff of Flintshire in 1799. On 12 December 1793 he married Louisa, second daughter of Sir Henry Peyton, settling at Rose Hill on the outskirts of Erbistock near Wrexham. They had one child, David [Pennant, junior] (1796–1835), an obituary for whom appeared in Gentleman’s Magazine, vol. XVI, New Series, 1841, p. 547. ODNB; LL, pp. 42–3; Evans, 'The life and work of Thomas Pennant', pp. 68–71; idem, 'The Flintshire Loyalist Association'.

Frequent references in the correspondence to Mrs Pennant's in Upper Grosvenour [sic] Street (a Mayfair Street, which runs eastward from Hyde Park, past Grosvenor Square) are to the home of Pennant's unmarried sister Catherine (1729–97). She had previously lived with her twin sister, Sarah (1729–80), at an address in St James's, Westminster, to which Pennant frequently referred his London acquaintance. Catherine was reputed for her generosity to her brother. Burke, A Genealogical and Heraldic History of the Commoners of Great Britain, vol. 3, p. 34; TP to [?Samuel Lysons], 6 January 1793, NYkPL, Pforz MS (MISC 0470); Peltz, 'The Extra-Illustration of London', p. 208, notes 74, 77; W. S. Lewis (ed.), The Yale Edition of Horace Walpole’s Correspondence, Vol. 2 (New Haven: Yale University Press, 1937), pp. 266, 267, @walpole.library.yale.edu.

Anne Pennant (née Mostyn) (d.1802) was the elder daughter of Sir Thomas Mostyn and his wife Sarah (née Western), and a sister to Sir Roger Mostyn, 5th baronet. She was Thomas Pennant's second wife whom he married at Whitford, Flintshire, in January 1777.

The genealogist Philip Yorke (1743–1804) was born at Erddig, near Wrexham. His interest in things Welsh began following his second marriage in 1782 to Diana, daughter of Piers Wynne of Dyffryn Aled, who was descended from Marchudd, lord of Uwch Dulas. In 1795 Yorke issued seventy copies of a genealogical history of Bleddyn ap Cynfyn, Tracts of Powys, which was dedicated to Thomas Pennant and contained letters from Lewis Morris to William Vaughan and others as an appendix. A revised and expanded edition of the Tracts, completed with the assistance of Walter Davies (Gwallter Mechain), appeared under the title of The Royal Tribes of Wales in 1799. A diffident parliamentarian, Yorke held the seats of Helston (1775–1781) and Grantham (1781–1792). ODNB; History of Parliament on-line. Letters from Yorke to Pennant are found at WCRO, CR2017/TP401/1–2, 4–5 (1777, 1778, 1786 and 1791) and NLW 15423C (1777).

Sir Ashton Lever (1729–1788), natural history collector. His collection of shells, minerals, stuffed animals and artefacts evolved into a museum, housed from 1773 in Leicester Square and open to visitors one day a week. The enterprise was beset by financial difficulties from 1783 and disposed of by a lottery in March 1786. Lever died of an apoplectic fit on 31 January 1788. A line engraving of him by W. Angus appeared in the European Magazine in 1784, and a stipple portrait by W. Nutter, after S. Shelley, was published in 1787. ODNB.

John Stuart, first marquess of Bute (1744–1814), diplomatist, was known in print collecting circles from the mid-1770s, often by the title 'Lord Mountstuart'. This was in recognition of his place of birth, Mount Stuart on the Scottish Isle of Bute, but also became his recognized title when he took the post of envoy to Turin for three years from August 1779. Son of John Stuart, third earl of Bute and prime minister during 1762–3, the first marquess inherited the south Wales estates of his wife's family of Windsor, and was created Baron Cardiff in 1776. In 1774, Stuart became the purchaser of Richard Bull's extra-illustrated version of James Granger, Biographical History of England. ODNB; History of Parliament on-line; Peltz, 'Engraved Portrait Heads', 39–44.
The Bearer (of the letter)

Thomas Hunt (c.1723–89), of Mollington, Cheshire, was MP for Bodmin from 1784 until his death at Chester on 11 October 1789. The Pennant/Bull correspondence shows that he spent time at an address in South Audley Street, Mayfair, and that he franked letters for Pennant. His anti-Pittite stance in Parliament would seem to make him a surprising friend to Bull and Pennant, but his Cornish and Cheshire connections may be seen as a reason for his acquaintance with them. History of Parliament on-line; The European Magazine, and London Review, vol. XVI (1789), 312.

The antiquary Sir William Burrell, second baronet (1732–1796), followed a legal career as advocate and was appointed chancellor of the diocese of Worcester in 1764. He came to title of baronet through his marriage, succeeding his father-in-law to the title in 1788. Elected FSA in 1754, by 1770 he was working on the history of Sussex. Thomas Pennant, A Journey from London to the Isle of Wight Volume II. From Dover to the Isle of Wight (London, 1801), p. 46, mentions him as the owner of ‘fine drawings’ of Herstmonceux Castle, East Sussex, which was dismantled in 1777, leaving only the outer walls standing. Pennant's regard for Burrell is apparent from the fact that he was one of the patrons for whom he produced an edition of his Tour in Wales on large paper with original Moses Griffith paintings as illustrations. ODNB s.v. Sir William Burrell; Moses Griffith.

Catherine, Countess of Desmond, was a reputed centenarian living in the fifteenth and sixteenth centuries, which Pennant found engraved from a painting in a Scottish collection in April 1773.

James Granger (bap. 1723, d. 1776), vicar of Shiplake, Oxfordshire, and a print collector and biographer, was renowned for his catalogue of engraved historical portraits, Biographical History of England from Egbert the Great to the Revolution (1769), and a supplement which followed in 1774. Granger worked closely with other connoisseurs of art, including Joseph Gulston, Horace Walpole and Richard Bull, with whom he discussed and exchanged prints. So popular was his work that the practice of ornamenting printed works with portraits and other prints became firmly associated with him and his name was lent to a verb, 'to grangerize', intended to describe this fashionable amateur occupation. ODNB; Peltz, 'Engraved Portrait Heads'.

fellow of Jesus College

Paul Panton, junior (1758–1822), son of Paul Panton of Bagillt, Flintshire, and his wife Jane, daughter of William Jones of Plas Gwyn, Anglesey. He was admitted to Lincolns Inn in 1775, began residing there in 1777 and kept his chambers there until 1794. He inherited his father's estates on the latter's death in 1797. Pennant notes that Paul Panton, junior, accompanied him on his tour of the Isle of Wight in 1774. ODNB s.v. Paul Panton (1727-1797); DWB s.v. Paul Panton (1727-1797); Literary life, p. 22.

John Ingleby (1749–1808) of Halkyn in Flintshire, a watercolour artist who worked on commission for Pennant from 1780 on north Wales views, largely urban, and as copyist of coats of arms and memorials. Pennant and Bull made greater use of Ingleby as illustrator following the death of his patron, Trench Chiswell, in February 1797. Evans, ‘Richard Bull and Thomas Pennant’, 275–6, 284–5; David Rowe, The A–Z of Curious Flintshire: Strange stories of mysteries, crimes and eccentrics (The History Press, 2015); Paul Joyner, Artists in Wales c.1740–c.1851 (Aberystwyth, 1997); <www.llgc.org.uk/discover/digital-gallery/pictures/inglebywatercolours/>. Pennant suggests him as an 'ingenious man' who can copy particular bits out of his book for Richard Bull.
in Vere Street Oxford Road

Sir Watkin Williams Wynn, fourth baronet (1749–1789), owner of the north Wales and border county estates of Wynnstay, Llanforda in Shropshire, Rhiwgoch in Merioneth, and Llwydiarth in Montgomeryshire. He shared his time between London (where he sat as MP from 1772) and Wynnstay, where he had a theatre built. His 1771 expedition in north Wales in the company of Paul Sandby, Thomas Apperley and others is believed to have given rise to a fashion for the picturesque in landscape. Sandby’s Views in North Wales (1776) was published as a result of this journey. Williams Wynn died at his Westminster home on 29 July 1789. ODNB.

James Robson (1733–1806), printer and bookseller, succeeded to the printing, bookselling and publishing business of his master, John Brindley, following the latter's death in 1758. The issuing of fixed-price and auction catalogues became a feature of his business, with his most notable auction, in conjunction with the Pall Mall bookseller, James Edwards, being that of the Pinelli collection in 1789 and 1790. ODNB.

Robert Faulder (fl.c.1780–1805), bookseller and publisher whose shop was located on the corner of Maddox Street and New Bond Street (and features in Gillray’s print, ‘The Carrot Seller’, O’Shea Gallery, Mayfair). Several of his publications included maps. Shops of London Map-Publishers @ www.mapforum.com/01/shops.htm.
bankers on Fleet Street

Paul Sandby (bap. 1731, d. 1809), painter and engraver, whose early career as a draughtsman to the military survey in Scotland gave him the opportunity to work on landscape drawings. Following a move to London in 1752, Sandby became increasingly involved in landscape work, employing various techniques (including pioneering use of aquatint), and exhibited work regularly at the Society of Artists and its successor, the Royal Academy. He was chief drawing master at the Royal Military Academy, Woolwich, 1768–1796, and was drawing master to patrons including Sir Watkin Williams Wynn. Drawings published following sketching tours in Wales in 1771 and 1773 and two further series of aquatints of Welsh subjects published in 1777 and 1786 helped to make Wales a popular destination for touring. ODNB.

Elizabeth Bull (1749–1809) and Catherine (d. 13 October 1795) were the daughters of Richard Bull and Mary, née Ash. Both shared their father’s interest in print collecting and were actively involved in pasting and decorating his volumes of engraved portrait heads and other extra-illustrated titles, Elizabeth described by a contemporary as 'deeply interested in her fathers [sic] favourite pursuit'. Neither married, possibly on account of the freedom that befell them on inheriting a substantial fortune through the death of Sir Humphry Morice. History of Parliament on-line; Peltz, 'Engraved Portrait Heads', p. 128; eadem, 'The Extra-Illustration of London', esp. pp. 500–11; and eadem, 'The extra-illustration of London: the gendered spaces and practices of antiquarianism in the late eighteenth century', in Myrone and Peltz (eds.), Producing the Past; W. P. Courtney, 'Richard Bull', Notes & Queries, 11th Series, 7 (March 1913), 170–1. For a contemporary account of the two sisters by their friend, Louisa Clarges, see Philip Olleson, The Journals and Letters of Susan Burney: Music and Society in Late Eighteenth-Century England (Routledge, 2016), p. 125

Morris Anthony Morris Storer (1746–1799), politician and collector, was the son of a wealthy West Indies merchant. He sat in Parliament as member for Carlisle, Cumbria (1774–80), and for Morpeth, Northumberland (1780–4), and was appointed by the Fox-North coalition as secretary of the embassy at Paris on 21 September 1783. The post of minister-plenipotentiary to which he was appointed on 13 December that year, was held only very briefly before the fall of the coalition, and Storer failed to be re-elected to parliament after 1784. He was an active collector of prints and books, and an important figure in the world of extra-illustration. Although his fervour for such activity was dampened in the early 1780s by financial difficulties, following his father's death in 1793 he inherited a substantial fortune. His collections were bequeathed to Eton College Library, and included copies of three extra-illustrated versions of Pennant's works: The journey from Chester to London; Some Account of London (2nd ed., 1791); and A tour in Wales (1784) and Journey to Snowdon (1783). He died of a ‘deep decline’ after years of poor health. ODNB; History of Parliament on-line; Peltz, 'Engraved Portrait Heads', 3–5; and ex inf. Lucy Peltz.

John Lloyd (1733–1793), son of John Lloyd (d. 1756), Bodidris, became curate at Caerwys, Flintshire in 1761 and was appointed rector there in 1778. Thomas Pennant in the 'Advertisement' to A tour in Wales. MDCCLXXVIII described him as 'my constant companion in these excursions'. Pennant relied heavily on Lloyd for translations of Welsh manuscript material, for his extensive knowledge of Welsh history, and for commentary on and correction of the early drafts of the Welsh tours. He was known to others, too, for his erudition: Iolo Morganwg visited him in 1772, Evan Evans in 1786, and he corresponded with Philip Yorke of Erddig, who shared his interest in genealogy. When he died on 22 May 1793, Pennant organized a fund to aid his widow Martha (d.1810), daughter of Francis Williams, with whom he had ten children. A 1780 portrait of Lloyd by Moses Griffith, engraved by Peter Mazell, appears in volumes extra-illustrated by both Pennant and Bull [extra-illustrated Tour in Wales TWO; Literary life, illustrated by Pennant and by Bull (NLW 12706E; NLW 550CE)]. For the re-engraved portrait by Griffith and Mazell (included in Literary life [immediately after list of contents]): 'The Reverend John Lloyd Rector of Caerwis: the constant friend companion & assistant to Thomas Pennant Esq.: in his Tours in Wales', M. Griffith del:; P. Mazel sc (n.p., c.1793). DWB; Paul Evans, 'Reverend John Lloyd of Caerwys (1733–93): Historian, Antiquarian and Genealogist', FHSJ, 31 (1983/1984), 109–124.

Elizabeth Bull (1749–1809) and Catherine (d. 13 October 1795) were the daughters of Richard Bull and Mary, née Ash. Both shared their father’s interest in print collecting and were actively involved in pasting and decorating his volumes of engraved portrait heads and other extra-illustrated titles, Elizabeth described by a contemporary as 'deeply interested in her fathers [sic] favourite pursuit'. Neither married, possibly on account of the freedom that befell them on inheriting a substantial fortune through the death of Sir Humphry Morice. History of Parliament on-line; Peltz, 'Engraved Portrait Heads', p. 128; eadem, 'The Extra-Illustration of London', esp. pp. 500–11; and eadem, 'The extra-illustration of London: the gendered spaces and practices of antiquarianism in the late eighteenth century', in Myrone and Peltz (eds.), Producing the Past; W. P. Courtney, 'Richard Bull', Notes & Queries, 11th Series, 7 (March 1913), 170–1. For a contemporary account of the two sisters by their friend, Louisa Clarges, see Philip Olleson, The Journals and Letters of Susan Burney: Music and Society in Late Eighteenth-Century England (Routledge, 2016), p. 125
first duke of Norfolk (1366–1399), subject fo a print

Born in Florence, the engraver Francesco Bartolozzi (1728–1815) was considered as the best engraver in Italy by the 1760s. Having had some of his work published in London in 1763, he was invited there by the art dealer Richard Dalton in 1764 and spent the next 35 years working there. He exhibited with the Society of Artists and thereafter at the Royal Academy, and established a vogue for dotted prints or 'stipples'. Most of his work was commanded by printsellers and he had others working for him including Luigi Schiavonetti and John Keyes Sherwin. In 1801 he moved to Lisbon to reform the royal printing press but died at his workshop there in 1815. ODNB. Named in NLW 5500C, no. 15; 16
Countess of Cumberland
Countess of Suffolk, Katherine Howard [nee Knyvett; other married name Rich]
Thomas Pennant's father
Thomas Pennant's mother
Thomas Pennant's son
née Jones; Moses Griffith's wife
Moses Griffith's son

Levinia Luther (née Bennett) (d. c.1807) was the daughter of Bennett Alexander Bennett and Mary (née Ash), of Ongar, Essex, but was raised from a young age by her mother's second husband, Richard Bull. She married John Luther (?1739–86), of Myles’s, near Ongar, in 1762, returning to her mother and step-father's home following the failure of the marriage in early 1764. She inherited the estate of Sir Humphry Morice (?1723–85), MP for Launceston and a close family friend, valued by a contemporary at £200,000, and appears to have lived at Morice's home, the Grove, Middlesex. It is likely that she was involved alongside her half-sisters in Bull's collecting activity and in pasting material into his extra-illustrated volumes. Pinkerton, 'Richard Bull of Ongar, Essex'', 46, 55; Peltz, 'The Extra-Illustration of London', vol. 2, pp. 503, 506–7, 507 n. 377; eadem, 'Bull-Granger Letterbook', p. 128; W. P. Courtney, 'Richard Bull', Notes & Queries, 11th Series, 7 (March 1913), 170–1; Richard Watson, Anecdotes of the Life of Richard Watson, Bishop of Landaff (Philadelphia: Abraham Small, 1818), pp. 26–7; Devon Record Office, 47/9/2/32a-b.
first Baron Herbert of Cherbury and first Baron Herbert of Castle Island
wife of Richard Herbert
Pennant's apothecary
Francesco Albano or Albani (1578-1660), painter
Richard Boyle, 3rd Earl of Burlington (1694-1753)
Elizabeth I (1533-1603); reigned 1558-1603
Tacksman at Coirechatacan in Skye. Hosts Pennant's party in 1772 and Johnson and Boswell in 1773
Son of Lachlan MacKinnon of Coirechatacan
Town Clerk of Campbeltown c.1772
Colonel Campbell of Kintyre?
Proprietor of Gigha c.1772
Principal proprietor of Islay c.1772

Eleazar Albin (d. 1742?), naturalist and watercolour painter, was probably of German origin, but had adopted the surname Albin by 1708, by which time he lived in Piccadilly. His three-volume publication, A Natural History of Birds (1731–8) involved the study of exotic birds owned by Thomas Lowther, duke of Chandos, and by the silk weaver and naturalist Joseph Dandridge, as well as of birds acquired at Newgate market and from sea captains and foreign merchants. It includes 306 plates, some of which may have been painted by Albin's daughter, Elizabeth (b. 1708). ODNB.

Lewis Bagot (1740–1802) was bishop of Bristol, Norwich and, from 1790, St Asaph, where he rebuilt the Bishops Palace, declaring his intention to spend most of his time in the diocese. Renowned for his high-church views and strong conservatism, he evinced anger and vitriol from dissenters. He was a friend of Pennant, with whom he corresponded and for whom he franked some of the letters in the Pennant/Bull correpondence. ODNB; NLW 15421C (L: St Asaph to Thomas Pennant, 30 September 1790); and WCRO CR2017/TP165/1 and /4 (14 August 1795 and n.d.).

Jean-Nicolas-Paul-François, vicomte de Barras (1755–1829), served on the Directory throughout its rule. He was particularly instrumental in bringing about the Fructidor coup of 4 September 1797, which lead to a series of purges and the instigation of radical policies until early 1798. He was eventually forced out of politics by Napoléon. Jones, The Longman Companion to the French Revolution, pp. 50, 51, 318.

James Basire (bap. 1730, d. 1802) was the eldest son of a printmaker and draughtsman whose publishing company he took over. His training included a period spent in Italy from 1749, alongside the artist, engraver, and antiquarian Richard Dalton. Back in London from late 1752, he began on a successful career as an etcher and engraver, one of the highlights of which was his appointment in succession to George Vertue as engraver to the Society of Antiquaries in 1759. This post led to constant employment, including work on plates for Charles Cordiner's Antiquities and Scenery of the North of Scotland (1780), and pioneering work on an engraving of the sixteenth-century painting known as The Field of the Cloth of Gold. In 1770 Basire was appointed engraver to the Royal Society. ODNB.

Richard Henry Alexander Bennett (?1742–1814), of North Court, Shorwell, Isle of Wight, was the son of Bennett Alexander Bennett and his wife Mary (née Ash), and the step-son of Richard Bull following his mother's marriage in 1747. He had one son, also named Richard Henry Alexander Bennett, and two daughters by his wife Elizabeth Amelia, daughter of Peter Burrell (1723–1775), and was MP for Newport, Cornwall, from 1770 to 1774. History of Parliament on-line; W. P. Courtney, 'Richard Bull', Notes & Queries, 11th Series, 7 (March 1913), 170–1, esp. 170.

Margaret Cavendish Bentinck (née Lady Margaret Cavendish Harley), duchess of Portland (1715–1785), daughter of Edward Harley, second earl of Oxford, was a collector of art and natural history specimens, and a patron of arts and sciences. Rousseau joined her on an expedition to the Peak District in 1766, and she botanized with her friend Mary Delany, especially from 1768, following the death of her husband. She also collected shells, art and virtu, and created a museum of natural curiosities at her London home in Privy Garden, Whitehall. ODNB.

Lady Georgiana Charlotte Bertie (1764–1838), daughter of Peregrine Bertie, third duke of Ancaster and Kesteven, and Mary Panton. She married George James Cholmondelay, first marquess of Cholmondelay, on 25 April 1791, thereafter taking his name. www.thepeerage.com.

John Boydell (1720–1804), engraver and printseller, was born Dorrington, Shropshire, but moved with his family to Hawarden, Flintshire, as a child. He was inspired to become an engraver after seeing a print of Hawarden Castle and the surrounding countryside and became apprenticed in 1741, aged twenty, for a firm of engravers in Holborn. He returned to Wales in 1748 to marry his sweetheart, Elizabeth Lloyd, and spent the honeymoon drawing views of Snowdonia, Welsh castles and the High Peak. He became an alderman in 1782, and was referred to after that as Alderman Boydell. ODNB.

James Brudenell, fifth earl of Cardigan (1725–1811), was a member of parliament for various constituencies in Dorset, Sussex and Wiltshire between 1754 and 1780. On 18 April 1781, at the age of 65, he married for the second time. His bride was the 32-year-old Lady Elizabeth Waldegrave (1758–1823), daughter of John, third Earl Waldegrave. History of Parliament on-line; www.thepeerage.com.

Nathaniel Samuel Buck (1696–1779), topographical draughtsman, engraver, and print publisher, and his brother Nathaniel (1724–1759) published 428 engravings of monasteries, abbeys, castles, and other ruins, three signed engravings of Fountains Abbey, two town plans, an engraving of Bristol high cross, and 87 long prospects of English and Welsh towns. Copper plates for printing these antiquities and the principal town prospects were acquired by the Fleet Street printer Robert Sayer, who reissued prints as single sheets or bound in three volumes as Buck's Antiquities in 1774. ODNB.

Nathaniel Samuel Buck (1696–1779), topographical draughtsman, engraver, and print publisher, and his brother Nathaniel (1724–1759) published 428 engravings of monasteries, abbeys, castles, and other ruins, three signed engravings of Fountains Abbey, two town plans, an engraving of Bristol high cross, and 87 long prospects of English and Welsh towns. Copper plates for printing these antiquities and the principal town prospects were acquired by the Fleet Street printer Robert Sayer, who reissued prints as single sheets or bound in three volumes as Buck's Antiquities in 1774. ODNB.
William Camden (1551–1623), historian and herald. His Britannia was published in 1586 with successive, enlarged editions in 1587, 1590, 1594, 1600, 1607 and a translation in 1610. ODNB.

George Carter (bap. 1737, d. 1794) entered the Royal Academy Schools in 1770, and travelled to Rome in 1774, returning to England by 1776. He exhibited at the Royal Academy in the late 1770s and again in the mid-1780, probably spending the years between 1779 and 1784 visiting Gibraltar and St Petersburg. An exhibition in Pall Mall, London, in 1785, showed his enterprise insomuch as it claimed that its contents had been 'painted without commission' and was on offer to 'any nobleman or gentleman who may wish to possess either the whole or a part of them'. It was not a success, but engravings after the pictures were received more positively. He sailed for India in December 1785, and auctioned some of his pictures there between November 1786 and January 1787. ODNB says that he left India 'about a year later'. ODNB.
John Carter (1748–1817), draughtsman and architect. He was employed in 1780 by the Society of Antiquaries to do drawing and etching work. His patrons included Richard Gough and Horace Walpole. ODNB.

François-Xavier de Belsunce de Castelmoron (1671–1755), Jesuit bishop of Marseille from 1709, was celebrated for his courage during the plague of 1720. A picture of him at the town-hall, giving benediction to the dying and dead, commemorates his devotion to his people during this time. He died at Marseille on 4 June 1755 and was granted a magnificent burial.

Richard Muilman Trench Chiswell (1735–1797), merchant banker and antiquary. He was known as Richard Muilman until December 1773, when he took the arms and names of his maternal grandparents. An avid collector of antiquarian books, Chiswell's library included four volumes of Pennant’s Tour in Wales, containing original coloured drawings and prints. He kept journals of tours in Derbyshire, the Lake District and Scotland, and Wales, undertaken between 1794 and 1796, and visited Pennant at Downing during the latter journey, also corresponding with him in 1794 and 1797. On 3 February 1797 he committed suicide at his home, Debden Hall, Essex, overcome by financial difficulties relating to his estates in West India. His copy of Pennant's The journey from Chester to London (1782), illustrated in four volumes, large-paper quarto, is housed at the Yale Centre for British Art, New Haven. ODNB; ex inf. Lucy Peltz.

George James Cholmondelay (1749–1827), fourth earl of Cholmondelay and, from 1815, first marquess of Cholmondelay. He held numerous offices and titles during his career including those of Lord-Lieutenant of Cheshire between 1779 and 1783, and Chamberlain of the same county from 1770 until 1827. In 1783 he was admitted to the Privy Council and was, between April and December of the same year, captain of the Yeomen of the Guard. He married Lady Georgiana Charlotte Bertie, daughter of Peregrine Bertie, third duke of Ancaster and Kesteven, on 25 April 1791. www.thepeerage.com.

Born in Montrose, Thomas Christie (1761–1796) abandoned a career in medicine for life as a political writer. He met Pennant at Downing during a tour of Britain in 1787, an account of which he wrote in a series of unpublished letters. His wide-ranging interests in several branches of literature led to the establishment of the Analytical Review, a review of books to which he contributed many of the articles in the initial volumes. Six months spent in Paris in early 1790 ensured his firm support of the Revolution and, in 1792, he returned to work on the English part of the new French constitution. ODNB; Nichols, Literary anecdotes, vol. 9, pp. 369–83.

Louisa Clarges (née Skrine; b. c. 1755, d. 1809), was known as the daughter of William Skrine and his first wife Jane Sumner, although it is not certain that Skrine was in fact her real father. In 1777 she married Sir Thomas Clarges, 3rd baronet (1751–82/3). After his death she made frequent visits to Italy, before settling in England in 1799. The children of the marriage included Thomas, who succeeded to his father's title on coming of age 25 December 1802; Louisa (d. 1806, aged 27); and William (1782–1807), but the Bull-Pennant correspondence suggests that there was another son, killed in naval service in 1794 (see TP189/53). Portraits of Lady Clarges were painted by Thomas Gainsborough and John Downman. On her relationship with Richard Bull's daughters, see BIOGRAPHIES: Elizabeth and Catherine Bull. History of Parliament on-line, s.v. Sir Thomas Clarges, 3rd Bt.; William Skrine; Edward A. Bloom and Lillian D. Bloom (eds.), The Piozzi Letters: Correspondence of Hester Lynch Piozzi, 1784–1821 (formerly Mrs. Thrale). Volume 4 1805–1810 (London and Toronto: Associated University Presses, 1996), pp. 95, note 29, 251–2, note 5; British Museum @ www.britishmuseum.org/search_ the_ collection_ database/term_details.aspx?biold=129174.

Richard Clarke of Newport, Isle of Wight, died in 1817, aged 80. He subscribed to books of sermons published in 1757 and 1786 and was included in a list of the governors and officers of the 'Asylum for the Support and Education of the Deaf and Dumb Children of the Poor', dated 1817. His connection with the leading Isle of Wight antiquarian of his day is shown by a bookplate, 'Given me by Sir Rd. Worsley', in Lincolnshire Archives (1 WORSLEY 10A). He corresponded directly with Pennant in 1793, and also answered his queries on the Isle of Wight at an unnamed date. Gentleman's Magazine, vol. LXXXVII, part 2 (1817), 89.

Sir Henry Clinton (1730–1795), an army officer, was raised to the rank of commander-in-chief during the American War of Independence. He returned to England in June 1782, where he found himself widely held responsible for the British defeat. Through the offices of influential friends from the time of the American war he was thereafter found a seat in parliament, where he had already served between 1774 and 1784, this time to represent Launceston (1790–4). Friends also secured him the post of governor of Gibraltar for 1794–5, but he died on 23 December 1795 before leaving Britain. He had three sons and two daughters from his marriage to Harriet, daughter of Thomas Carter, as well as five children with a mistress from the period of the American war, and another illegitimate daughter. ODNB; History of Parliament on-line.

Richard Clough (d.1570), known by Welsh contemporaries as Rhisiart Clwch. The son of a Denbigh glover, he developed a career as a merchant and agent for the House of Gresham, under its royal agent, Thomas Gresham. A grant of leaseholds in Wales in 1564 enabled him to complete the building of two properties in his native county of Denbigh, Bachegraig and Clough Hall (Plas Clough), by 1567. For Moses Griffith’s c.1775 copy of an anonymous Elizabethan portrait of Clough see http://www.llgc.org.uk/digitalmirror/jts/JTS00006/69/tudalen.html?Ing=en.; and for late eighteenth-century line engravings of Clough by James Basire, after Moses Griffith, see NPG, nos. NPG D25450, D33536.

Sir George Cornewall, 2nd Bt. (1748–1819), of Moccas Court, Herefordshire, represented his home county in parliament during 1774–96 and 1802–7. He was the son of a London merchant, Sir George Amyand, from whom he inherited a share in a banking firm, but assumed the name of his wife Catherine, daughter and heir of Velters Cornewall. History of Parliament on-line.

James Edwards (1756–1816), book collector and bookseller, was established in business at Pall Mall, London, from 1784. He purchased and sold at auction the private libraries of English collectors and antiquaries, later expanding his interest to continental libraries through several trips abroad. In 1788 he purchased the Pinelli Library in Venice, producing a catalogue entitled Bibliotheca Pinelliana in advance of its sale in March 1789. ODNB.

Thomas Erskine, first Baron Erskine (1750–1823), lord chancellor. He was involved in the trial of William Davies Shipley for seditious libel at the Shrewsbury Assizes in August 1784, where he managed to arrest judgement in the case on the grounds that the indictment was defective. In the 1790s, Erskine became an enthusiast for the French Revolution, and lawyer for the defence in the treason trials of 1794, where he argued that the London Corresponding Society sought parliamentary reform through constitutional means. In 1770 Erskine married Frances (d. 1805), daughter of Daniel Moore, with whom he had four sons and four daughters. ODNB; History of Parliament on-line.

William Faden (1749–1836), engraver and cartographer. His entry into map making came in 1773 through a partnership with the family of Thomas Jeffreys, St Martin's Lane. During the years of the American War of Independence he produced accurate maps and atlases of historical note. In 1783 he was appointed 'Geographer in Ordinary to his Majesty' and through contact with mapmakers throughout Europe he was able to supply government departments with maps and to commission new surveys. Faden published twenty-five maps of English counties during 1749–96. ODNB, COPAC.

The Rev. James Falconer (1737–1809), archdeacon of Derby and prebendary of Lichfield, was brother-in-law to Thomas Pennant through his first marriage to Elizabeth (née Falconer). James and Elizabeth were children of James Faulkner of Chester, Lieutenant, and his wife Elizabeth (née Inge).

Thomas Fitzmaurice (1742–93), of Llewenny [or put as Lleweni throughout] Hall, Denbighshire. He held the parliamentary seats of Calne, Wiltshire (1762–74), and Chipping Wycombe, Buckinghamshire (1774–80), and was sheriff of Denbighshire in 1781–2. In 1776 he purchased Llewenny, where he established a bleaching factory. His new calling as a linen merchant was an attempt to save himself from financial difficulties brought on by unprofitable estates in Ireland. A contemporary, Richard Twining, wrote that ‘The buildings which he has erected, and the machines and apparatus which he has placed in them are really astonishing’, and mentioned the shop which Fitzmaurice opened in Chester to sell the bleached linen. In 1777 he married Lady Mary O'Brien, daughter of Murrough, 5th Earl of Inchiquin [I], by Mary, s.j. Countess of Orkney. She inherited her mother's title and her estate of Cliveden in 1790, and the couple settled in Buckinghamshire thereafter. History of Parliament on-line.

John Fitzpatrick, second Earl of Upper Ossory (1745–1818) and, from 1794, Baron Upper Ossory of Ampthill, Bedfordshire. In 1763 he travelled to Italy where he bought old paintings by the masters and commissioned further works from the Scottish history painter Gavin Hamilton. He was MP for Bedfordshire, 1767–94, and associated with Whig politicians including Horace Walpole and Charles James Fox. History of Parliament on-line; Ilaria Bignamini and Clare Hornsby, Digging and Dealing in Eighteenth-Century Rome, vols. 1 and 2 (2010), pp. 334-335.

George, Prince of Wales, later George IV (1762–1830), was the far-from-dutiful eldest son of George III. ‘[R]ather too fond of wine and women’, he had numerous affairs and constant debts. His refurbishing of his mansion, Carlton House, and work on the Marine Pavilion in Brighton were carried out at great expense, and his marriage to Mrs Maria Fitzherbert, a Roman Catholic, in December 1785 without the king's consent was illegal. George III's illness, which steadily worsened from the latter part of 1788, led to the Regency Bill of 12 February 1789, but the king was on the mend before his son needed to take over. George married his cousin Caroline, daughter of the duke of Brunswick, on 8 April 1795, with a view to settling his debts. ODNB.

Messrs. Goslings' bank in Fleet Street was founded 1650. The firm was known from 1796 as Messrs. Goslings and Sharpe (Pennant refers to his bankers as Mess Gosling & Sharpe in January 1797) when John Charles Sharpe joined the partnership. British History Online, digitized version of Old and New London: Volume 1 (London, 1878) @ www.british-history.ac.uk/old-new-london/vol1/pp32-53.

John Greenwood (1727–1792), portrait painter and auctioneer. Born in Boston, Massachusetts, Greenwood worked in the Dutch colony of Surinam from 1752, at Amsterdam from 1758 and, from 1763, settled in London, where he became a respected and successful auctioneer, and an early member and, later, a director of the Incorporated Society of Artists of Great Britain. ODNB.

Joseph Gulston (1744/5–1786), book and art collector and connoisseur. A halfhearted politician, he twice held the parliamentary seat for Poole (1765–8 and 1780–4), but his main passion was book- and print-collecting, which he was enabled to do on inheriting a fortune of £250,000 in funds following the death of his father in 1766. Together with his wife, Elizabeth (née Stepney), an artist and etcher, he built a collection of books and prints, including 23,500 British and 18,000 foreign portraits, earning a reputation for rapaciousness. His extravagance gradually led to financial ruin, which he attempted to counteract by the sale in 1775 of his home, Ealing Grove in Middlesex (lavishly transformed into an Italianate villa following his marriage), and of his book and print collections (in 1783/4 and early 1786 respectively). He died on 16 July 1786. ODNB; History of Parliament on-line; Gentleman's Magazine, vol. LVI, part the second (1786), 622.

The diplomatist James Harris, first earl of Malmesbury (1746–1820), was responsible for British foreign policy from late 1786 and involved in negotiations relating to the Dutch Patriot Revolt of 1787. In February 1788 he became an ambassador, but his support of Fox during the 1789 Regency crisis briefly put him out of favour with Pitt. During the 1790s he was entrusted with several weighty diplomatic missions, however, including that to Paris from October 1796 and Lille between early July and mid-September 1797. ODNB.

Warren Hastings (1732–1818), appointed governor of Bengal in 1772, was a good linguist and showed an appreciation of Indian culture. He retired in 1785 but was impeached on 10 May 1787 largely due to the efforts of Edmund Burke, who held him responsible for the rapacious policies of the East India Company in its provinces, its exploitation of its allies, and its wars. The prosecution closed its case on 30 May 1791 but further prosecution speeches were delivered in 1794 before a large majority of the Lords voted ‘not guilty’ the following year. ODNB.

Jacob van Heemskerk (1567–1607), Dutch explorer, then admiral in command of the Dutch fleet at the 1607 battle of Gibraltar. In this battle, he successfully led an unexpected attack on the Spanish fleet, anchored at the Bay of Gibraltar, but was killed by a cannon ball wound to his leg.

C. Hoare & Co was founded by Sir Richard Hoare (1648–1719). His grandson, Henry Hoare (1705–1785) succeeded his father, also named Henry Hoare (1677–1725), as a partner of Hoare's Bank in 1726, but, in settling his Stourhead estate in Wiltshire on his grandson, Colt Hoare, stipulating that every contact between the latter and the bank be severed. The bank instead went to Colt's father, Richard Hoare. ODNB; Victoria Hutchings, Messrs Hoare, Bankers: A History of the Hoare Banking Dynasty (London: Constable, 2005).

Hans Holbein, the younger (1497/8–1543), artist, was born in southern Germany but had moved to Basel in Switzerland by 1515. Here, he was appointed town painter, and worked on wall paintings, notable for their representation of moving figures, as well as designs for Basel's printers, including his series Dance of Death (1520s; published in the 1530s). He spent two periods in England, between 1526 and 1528, and again from 1531/2 to 1543, working on his second visit as painter to Henry VIII and for other patrons, including German Hanseatic merchants resident in London. The Hanseatic community commissioned two large canvas works from Holbein, The Triumph of Riches and The Triumph of Poverty, which are preserved only through seventeenth-century copies by Lucas Vorsterman. ODNB.

The etcher Wenceslaus Hollar (1607–1677) was born in Prague, Bohemia, but lived in London between 1636 and 1644, and again from c.1651. His English patrons included the publisher John Ogilby and the antiquary and herald Sir William Dugdale, and his work included etchings of women's costumes, including muffs; copies of paintings and drawings by artists such as Holbein and Leonardo da Vinci; topographical prints and maps; and drawings made during his a period spent at Tangier in 1669. ODNB.

Samuel Hooper (d. 1793), bookseller, kept shops in the Strand, Ludgate Street, and then in High Holborn. Well-known as the publisher of Francis Grose’s The Antiquities of England and Wales, he held meetings between contemporary literary characters. Coleman, ‘The Third Edition of Grose’s Classical Dictionary of the Vulgar Tongue, p. 78; Gentleman’s Magazine (February 1793), 'Obituaries', 190; Julie Coleman, ‘The Third Edition of Grose’s Classical Dictionary of the Vulgar Tongue: Bookseller’s Hackwork or Posthumous Masterpiece?’ in Julie Coleman and Anne McDermott, Historical Dictionaries and Historical Dictionary Research: Papers from the International Conference on Historical Lexicography and Lexicology, at the University of Leicester, 2002 (Tübingen, 2004), pp. 71–82, esp. pp. 78–9.
Pennant took into his service as secretary, Thomas, son of 'Roger Jones, our parish clerk', on 1 January 1790. Literary life, p. 39.

Andrew Kippis (1725–1795), Presbyterian minister and biographer. Born and brought up in the East Midlands, Kippis was appointed minister of the Presbyterian congregation at Princes Street, Westminster, in 1753 and remained there until his death. His biography of Cook, The life of captain James Cook was published in London in 1788 [ODNB wrongly gives the date as 1778]. ODNB.

Sir Henry Lee (1533–1611), courtier, and favourite of Elizabeth I. He was the subject of several portraits, most famously that of Anthonis Mor, 1568, probably made during a visit by Lee to Antwerp. See NPG, no. 2095, and for further portraits ODNB.

Charles Lennox (1735–1806), third duke of Richmond, third duke of Lennox, and duke of Aubigny in the French nobility. He followed a military career until 1760 and retained his interest in the military thereafter through his involvement from 1763 in the Sussex militia. He had a particular interest in art and created a sculpture gallery in his home, open to painters, carvers, sculptors and other artists ‘to whom the study of statuary might be useful’. ODNB.

Daniel Lysons (1727–1800), physician [see five letters in Warwickshire County record office, 1764, 1767], and his two nephews, the antiquary Samuel Lysons (bap. 1763, d. 1819), and his brother, the historical topographer Daniel Lysons (1762–1834). The brothers collaborated on Magna Britannia, being a concise topographical account of the several counties of Great Britain. They made personal visits to collect materials, circulated printed questionnaires, and the first volume of the work (covering Bedfordshire Berkshire and Buckinghamshire) was published in 1806. ODNB.

Daniel Lysons (1727–1800), physician [see five letters in Warwickshire County record office, 1764, 1767], and his two nephews, the antiquary Samuel Lysons (bap. 1763, d. 1819), and his brother, the historical topographer Daniel Lysons (1762–1834). The brothers collaborated on Magna Britannia, being a concise topographical account of the several counties of Great Britain. They made personal visits to collect materials, circulated printed questionnaires, and the first volume of the work (covering Bedfordshire Berkshire and Buckinghamshire) was published in 1806. ODNB.

Daniel Lysons (1727–1800), physician [see five letters in Warwickshire County record office, 1764, 1767], and his two nephews, the antiquary Samuel Lysons (bap. 1763, d. 1819), and his brother, the historical topographer Daniel Lysons (1762–1834). The brothers collaborated on Magna Britannia, being a concise topographical account of the several counties of Great Britain. They made personal visits to collect materials, circulated printed questionnaires, and the first volume of the work (covering Bedfordshire Berkshire and Buckinghamshire) was published in 1806. ODNB.

George Macartney, Earl Macartney (1737–1806), diplomatist and colonial governor. His numerous diplomatic posts involved work as envoy to Russia, Chief Secretary in Ireland, Governor of Madras, an embassy to Peking, a mission to Verona to the exiled Louis the 18th, and the post of governor of the Cape. The embassy to China was undertaken for the joint purposes of the East India Company and the government, who wished to improve conditions for trade with China. A party of 94, including many experts, sailed on the Lion on 26 September 1792 with samples of the best of British manufactures, which were presented to the Emperor of China on 14 September 1793. Macartney was unable to ensure a treaty of trade and friendship and was handed his dismissal on 3 October 1793. Nonetheless he was raised to an earldom in the Irish peerage in 1794 following his return, via the southern Chinese province of Canton.

Humphrey Minchin (1727–1796), of Holywell, Droxford, Hampshire. He served the borough of Okehampton, Devonshire, on the interest of Lord Spencer until 1790, but was obliged to renounce his seat at the dissolution of parliament in that year, following an earlier decision to support Pitt against his patron's wishes. Later that year he was returned for the borough of Bossiney, also in Devonshire. Minchin repeatedly (but without success) applied for an Irish peerage, noting his connexions and property in Ireland. More profitably he was granted military posts, including that of lieutenant-colonel of the North Hampshire militia from 1793 until his death. History of Parliament on-line.

Politician and art collector Humphry Morice (1723–1785) inherited from his second cousin, Sir William Morice, third baronet, a picture collection including paintings of recent British heroes, commissioned from Venetian and Bolognese artists. The inheritance also brought the boroughs of Launceston and Newport in Cornwall under his control, but much of his time was spent in Naples, where he worked on enlarging his art collection and where he died on 18 October 1785. ODNB; History of Parliament on-line.

Sir Thomas Mostyn, sixth baronet (1776–1831) of Mostyn, Flintshire, and Gloddaeth, Caernarvonshire. The only son of Sir Roger Mostyn, 5th baronet, he succeeded his father on 26 July 1796. In the election to represent Flintshire, held on 8 November 1796, he defeated John Lloyd and Lloyd Kenyon by 52 to 30 and 10 votes respectively; but was replaced by John Lloyd on petition on 12 June 1797. On 8 November 1799 Lloyd vacated his seat and was replaced by Sir Thomas Mostyn, who continued to represent Flintshire until 17 April 1831. Born on 20 October 1776 Mostyn would have been 20 years old when he first entered Parliament, and therefore not of age, as Pennant mentions in NLW 5500C, no. 130. History of Parliament online; correspondence relating to Mostyn's election in 1796 is found in NLW, Glynne of Hawarden, letters dated 3, 7, 11 August 1796.

Sir William Musgrave, sixth baronet (1735–1800), administrator, print collector and antiquary. Active in both the Royal Society and the Society of Antiquaries, he was known as one of the foremost collectors of engraved British portrait prints, with a collection to rival that of Horace Walpole. His collection, alongside those of Walpole and James West, formed the bases of Granger's Biographical History of England (1769). Musgrave also compiled lists and indexes, including a ‘General catalogue of engraved portraits both British and foreign’. ODNB.

Treadway Russell Nash (1725–1811), Church of England clergyman and antiquary. He lived Bevere near Worcester from 1758 and published Collections for a History of Worcestershire, containing many engravings, mostly by James Ross of Worcester, in two volumes in 1781 and 1782. He bequeathed paintings and engravings collected on his grand tour (1749–51) to Worcester College (where they remain), and personal papers to Eastnor Castle, but eight grangerized volumes of the Collections, sold in 1901, were subsequently destroyed in a house fire. Pennant's close relationship with him is evinced from several references to visits to him at Bevere in the Pennant-Bull correspondence. ODNB.

John Nichols (1745–1826), printer and writer. He became proprietor of the printing house of William Bowyer on the latter’s death in 1777. He purchased a share in the Gentleman’s Magazine in 1778 and by 1792 held entire editorial control. Under his editorship the magazine doubled in size and increased its emphasis on biographical material. ODNB s.v. Nichols family.

Louis Philippe Joseph duc d’Orléans (1747–1793) led a dissipated life but became interested in politics in the late 1780s. He was a critic of the first Assembly of Notables in 1787 and of the second Assembly in 1788. Elected to both the Estates General and the National Convention, he voted for the execution of Louis XVI, before presumed links to Dumouriez led to his own arrest and execution. He was sent on a mission to Britain between October 1789 and July 1790, where he enjoyed a friendship with George, Prince of Wales. Jones, The Longman Companion to the French Revolution, p. 376; Tom Ambrose, Godfather of the Revolution: The Life of Phillippe Égalité, Duc D'Orléans (London: Peter Owen, 2008).

John Palmer (1742–1818), theatre proprietor and postal reformer. Theatre work between London and Bristol convinced Palmer of the need for improved communications, involving the replacement of the post boy with a small cart by mail coaches equipped with a box watched over by an armed guard and able to ensure the prompt dispatch of mail. The coaches were exempt from tolls and granted priority over other vehicles so that the momentum of their journeys was sustained. There were differences with the post office, but Palmer shouldered the cost of the reform, in which Pitt had shown an interest. In August 1786, the post office appointed him on suitable terms but his position was not confirmed until July 1789. Pennant was infuriated by the issue of the mail coaches, and expressed his views in A letter to a Member of Parliament, on Mail-Coaches (London: R. Faulder, 1792). ODNB.

Richard Pennant, Baron Penrhyn (c.1737–1808), a slate manufacturer and politician, who shared with Thomas Pennant descent from a fifteenth-century abbot of Basingwerk. Both Richard Pennant's parents inherited substantial plantations in Jamaica, and Richard added to the family wealth the Penrhyn estate in Caernarvonshire, through his marriage to Anne Susannah Warburton (1745–1816) in 1765. A member of parliament for Liverpool (1767–1780; 1784–1790), he opposed William Wilberforce’s campaign for the abolition of slavery in 1787, and the following year spoke in the House of Commons in defence of slave traders and planters. In 1782 the medieval Penrhyn Hall was remodelled by Samuel Wyatt. For correspondence between Richard Pennant and Thomas Pennant see WCRO, TP 328 /1–3, c.1796–8; and NLW 2594E, Carnarvonshire folder. ODNB.

Thomas Pennant, junior (1780–1845), the son of Thomas Pennant and his second wife, Anne (née Mostyn). He became rector of Weston Turville, Bucks, married Caroline, daughter of Thomas Griffith of Rhual, and died without issue. ODNB; John Burke, A genealogical and heraldic history of the commoners of Great Britain and Ireland, enjoying territorial possessions or high official rank; but uninvested with heritable honours (4 vols., London: Henry Colburn, 1836), III, p. 34.

Charles Rainsford (1728–1809), of Soho Square, Middlesex, was a professional army officer, who also held three different parliamentary seats during his career, including that of the borough of Newport in Cornwall between 1790 and 1796. He made several promotions through the ranks, from brigadier-general (1762) to major-general (1777), lieutenant-general (1782) and general (1796). During his career he saw service at home, including the office of governor of Chester, 1776–96, as well as service abroad, notably in Gibraltar between 1793 and March 1795. He was a fellow of the Society of Antiquaries and the Royal Society, and left a substantial number of manuscripts, including papers and letters related to his time in service abroad. ODNB; History of Parliament on-line.

William Richardson (fl. 1778–1812), known as 'William Richardson Junior', probably followed his father into trade as a print dealer and publisher. Alongside John Thane, he became a leading specialist in portrait prints, and his series of facsimiles of rare early British portraits were highly valued by extra-illustrators. The title of his catalogue, Richardson’s Catalogue. A Collection of English and Foreign Portraits, topography and historical prints … with prices affixed (London, 1791), corroborates Pennant's favourable impression of him. COPAC; www.britishmuseum.org.

John Keyse Sherwin (bap. 1751, d.1790), designer and engraver, was the son of a shipyard labourer. His talent for drawing was discovered by William Mitford, on whose estate near Petworth, Sussex, Sherwin worked as a gardener in 1769. This led to study in London, where he was taught to engrave by Francis Bartolozzi, with whom he stayed until 1774. Contemporaries mention his ‘vanity’ and ‘impudent assurance’. He died in straitened circumstances on 20 September 1790. ODNB.

Pitt appointed George John Spencer, second Earl Spencer (1758–1834), to the post of first lord of the Admiralty on 17 December 1794. He was particularly influential and successful in his choice of commanders for significant theatres in the war against Revolutionary France. ODNB.

William Davies Shipley (1745–1826), son of Dr Jonathan Shipley, Bishop of St Asaph, was appointed Dean of the cathedral of St Asaph in 1774. Through his marriage to the daughter and heiress of Ellis Yonge, Bryn Yorkin, near Wrexham, his family became one of the wealthiest in north Wales. In December 1784 he was tried for seditious libel after publishing an edition of a reformist pamphlet by Sir William Jones but, following a hearing and a trial at Wrexham and Shrewsbury, was exonerated at the King's Bench in December. He arrived home to a rapturous welcome from the people of north-east Wales, but was viewed with suspicion by Government sympathisers, including Pennant, thereafter. ODNB; Michael J. Franklin, ‘Sir William Jones, the Celtic Revival and the Oriental Renaissance’, in Gerard Carruthers and Alan Rawes (eds.), English Romanticism and the Celtic World (Cambridge, 2003), pp. 20–37; A. Cynfael Lake, ‘Rhai Ystyriaethau Pellach Ynghylch Awduraeth Yr Anterliwt Goll’, NLWJ, XXVII, no. 3 (1992), 337–49.

Thomas Skinner (1737–1806) became alderman for the ward of Queenhithe in the City of London in 1785 and was appointed lord mayor of London in 1794. He was active in reforming the conditions of prisons and some aspects of the inhumane treatment of convicted criminals in London. His lucrative career as an auctioneer began in the late 1750s and, in spite of a lack of powers of eloquence and rhetoric, an obituary noted that he achieved 'an unprecedented degree of celebrity, and . . . acquired more wealth than any other individual in that profession'. The monthly magazine and British register, vol. 21, no. 1 (1806), 177–9.

Benjamin Smith may be the engraver to whom Pennant and Bull refer in letters dated 25 August 1790 and 3 February 1791. He was a pupil of Bartolozzi, working from different addresses in London in 1786 and 1805. Exeter Working Papers. Named [as 'Mr Smith' and 'Smith the Engraver'] in NLW 5500C, no. {89}.

Benjamin Stillingfleet (1702–1771), botanist and writer. His close friendship with Pennant is attested by the fact that he left a small number of his manuscript to him, although the majority were ordered to be burnt. ODNB. His correspondence with Pennant between 1761 and 1771 is found at WCRO, CR 2017/TP367/1–17. A portrait in oil on canvas by Johann Joseph Zoffany, c. 1761, together with examples of mezzotints by Valentine Green, after Zoffany, 1782, are found at the National Portrait Gallery – NPG 6477; NPG D42144; NPG D42145; NPT D42146. Pennant included a print, with a cutting from the colophon of a letter and Stillingfleet's signature in his extra-illustrated MS copy of Literary life (NLW 12706E).

E. Stringer, an artist active in the Lichfield area in the 1780s. His work includes 'A Perspective View of a part of the City of Lichfield', and 'View near Lichfield, with large Willow Tree', both dated 1785. He is recommended to Richard Gough by Richard Greene, writing from Lichfield on 3 December 1786, and referred to again by the latter in a letter of 9 July 1787 to Gough, where his work on 'drawings of the tombs in Bromsgrove Church' is mentioned. Nichol, Illustrations of the Literary History of the Eighteenth Century, vol. VI, p. 325; Catalogue of Maps, Prints, Drawings, Etc. Forming the Geographical and Topographical Collection Attached to the Library of His Late Majesty King George the Third, and Presented by his Majesty King George the Fourth to the British Museum (London: British Museum, 1829), vol. 1, p. 616; John Britton, Historical and Descriptive Account of the Cathedrals of Winchester, Lichfield, and Oxford; With Numerous Engravings: forming Volume III. of The Cathedral Antiquities (London, 1836), p. 69.

John Thane (1747?–1818), dealer in prints, medals and manuscripts. He began publishing regular catalogues of his retail stock of prints but was also an important collector in his own right. His three-volume British autography: a collection of facsimiles of the handwriting of royal and illustrious personages, with their authentic portraits was published during 1788–91. ODNB; Peltz, 'Bull-Granger Letterbook', p. 78.

John Turton (1735–1806), physician, began studying medicine in 1761 at Leiden and graduated BM from University College, Oxford, in 1762 and DM in 1767. Elected fellow of the Royal Society in 1763 and of the Royal College of Physicians in 1768, he settled in London from 1767 and soon had a large practice, including the queen's household, the queen herself and, from 1797, the king and the prince of Wales. ODNB.

George Vertue (1684–1756), engraver and antiquary. He was official engraver to the Society of Antiquaries from 1717 until his death, a researcher into the history of art in Britain, and an independent print publisher. ODNB; Martin Myrone, 'Graphic antiquarianism in eighteenth-century Britain: the career and reputation of George Vertue (1684–1756)', in idem and Peltz (eds.), Producing the Past, pp. 35–54.

Horatio [Horace] Walpole, fourth earl of Orford (1717–1797), of Strawberry Hill, Middlesex, author, politician and patron of the arts. He was son of the Whig politician and prime minister Sir Robert Walpole, first earl of Orford, and held parliamentary seats between 1741 and 1768. From 1746 he made his home in a small house at Windsor, which he transformed into a 'little Gothic castle', under the name of Strawberry Hill, adding new rooms, including a library, in 1754. His interest in portraiture was sparked by his acquaintance, from 1743, with George Vertue, and led to the publication of Anecdotes of Painting in England (2 vols., 1762; vol. 3 1764), a work which he highly prized among his oeuvre. ODNB; History of Parliament on-line.

John Wingrave (1729–1807) worked as a bookbinder from various London addresses, mostly in Fleet Street, c. 1767–1805. He was an acquaintance of the freed slave Ignatius Sancho, who wrote several letters to him and to his wife and son. Exeter Working Papers in Book History @bookhistory.blogspot.com; Brycchan Carey, 'Ignatius Sancho's Friends and Family', @brycchancarey.com/sancho/friends.htm.

Sir Richard Worsley (1751–1805), seventh baronet of Appuldurcombe House, near Wroxall on the Isle of Wight. Worsley completed The History of the Isle of Wight (1781), begun by his father and grandfather. He sat as MP for Newport on the Isle of Wight intermittently between 1774 and 1801, resigning in 1784 to travel to the continent, to return in 1788. Whilst abroad, he acquired a collection of statues, reliefs and gems, including Greek marbles, bringing it back to Appuldurcombe and publishing an illustrated description of it in Museum Worsleyanum (2 parts; 1798, 1802). He spent another period abroad as envoy to the Venetian republic, 1793–7. ODNB; History of Parliament on-line.

Henry Penruddocke Wyndham (1736–1819), topographer. He set out on the grand tour in 1765, already aged 29. Convinced of the superiority of the English way of life, he toured Wales in 1774, publishing an anonymous account of this journey, A Gentleman’s Tour through Monmouthshire, and Wales, the following year. He revisited Wales in 1777, accompanied by the Swiss watercolour painter Samuel Hieronymous Grimm, and in 1781 published Tour through Monmouthshire and Wales. He was elected a fellow of the Society Antiquaries in 1777 and of the Royal Society 1783, and was member of Parliament for Wiltshire, 1795–1812.

An Italian painter whose early work included a painting at Florence of the whole history of the Passion, a work completed alongside his brother Taddeo, also an artist, in just four days. In 1574, having left Rome, where he worked for pope Gregory XIII, Zucchero reached England. Work carried out there included portraits of Elizabeth I and of Mary, Queen of Scots, later engraved by George Vertue, together with a self-portrait. He also copied 'The Triumphs of riches and poverty', two large pictures painted in distemper by Hans Holbein in the hall of the Easterling merchants at the Hanseatic League's Steelyard in London. Horace Walpole, Anecdotes of painting in England (London: Thomas Farmer at Strawberry Hill, 1762), I, pp. 83, 140–3.
George Vanden Bempde (1720–92), 3rd Marquess of Annandale, owner of Hackness Hall, a country house a few miles west of Scarborough. He was declared a lunatic by an inquest in Chancery in 1748.
Mary Hartley (c. 1738–1803), Bath-based artist and bluestocking correspondent, daughter of David Hartley.
Sir Henry Carr Ibbotson (d. 1825), of Denton Park, Otley.
Hugh Percy (c. 1714–86), 1st Duke of Northumberland.
Elizabeth Percy (nee Seymour; 1716–76), Duchess of Northumberland.
Gabriel Piozzi (1741–1809), musician. Second husband of Hester Thrale (nee Salusbury).
John Ker, 3rd Duke of Roxburghe(1740–1804)
Skye landowner
Skye landowner
Skye landowner or tacskman
Father of John Stuart of Killin and Luss,
Rev Prof John Walker (1731–1803), Regius Professor of Natural History at Edinburgh (1779–1803)
Author of The Man of Feeling (1771)
Henry Dundas (1742– 1811)
Owner of Mavisbank
Henry Stuart (1545–67), styled Lord Darnley until 1565.
William Forbes, (c.1670-1745), first regius professor of Law at Glasgow University, author of <hi rend="italic">The Institutes of the Law of Scotland</hi> (1772-1730).
Heretor at Luss c.1773
Signatory of a poem about Ben Lomond, engraved on a window pane in the inn at Tarbet, often commented on and transcribed by travellers.
Owners of Lady Frederick Campbell - Campbells of Shawfield?
Engaged to Robert Ramsay in 1774
Willielma Campbell (1741-1786) was a benefactor of the Society for Promoting Christian Knowledge.
Proprietor in Breadalbane
King George III
Farmer, proprietor of Achessan in Breadalbane c.1774
Agricultural improver and resident at Auchlyne, Glendochart c.1774
Involved in the preservatio of the roe deer population in Glenlyon.
(d.1797) Wife to Reverend McIntyre of Glenorchy.
